thread.title: ACCC holds up Foxtel's bid for 15% of Ten
thread.title_full: ACCC holds up Foxtel's bid for 15% of Ten

title: ACCC holds up Foxtel's bid for 15% of Ten
text:
Mon, Sep 14, 2015, 10:12 AM AEST - Australia Markets close in 5 hrs 48 mins ACCC holds up Foxtel's bid for 15% of Ten AAP – 9 minutes ago Print 
Foxtel's bid for a 15 per cent stake in Network Ten has been held up after the competition watchdog expressed concern the move could increase the amount of sport shown exclusively on the pay-TV platform. 
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is also worried that Foxtel's financial muscle could give Ten a big advantage over its free-to-air rivals when it comes to sport broadcast rights. 
The watchdog has asked for more information on, and reaction to, the proposed $77 million deal, setting a September 28 deadline for submissions. 
It will announce a final decision on October 22. 
ACCC chairman Rod Sims said the proposal, under which Foxtel would take up 50 per cent of a $154 capital raising by Ten, could lead to other free-to-air networks being unable to compete for sports broadcast rights in the face of joint bids by Ten and Foxtel. 
"The proposed acquisitions ... could enhance Ten's ability to acquire the rights to sports, including premium sports, and could increase the likelihood of more sport being shown exclusively on Foxtel," Mr Sims said. 
"Given the importance of sporting content to a broadcaster's ability to compete strongly with other free-to-air networks, the ACCC is concerned that the advantage Ten would gain in acquiring sporting content may lead to a substantial lessening of competition in the free-to-air television market." 
The ACCC also expressed concern over whether the deal would decrease competition for advertising revenue in an industry already struggling on that front. 
Ten has suffered years of declining ratings and advertising revenue, despite funding injections from its list of heavyweight shareholders, which include Gina Rinehart, James Packer and Lachlan Murdoch. 
As part of the deal, Ten would take a 24.99 per cent stake in Foxtel's advertising business, Multi Channel Network, which would also become a sales representative for the free to air broadcaster. 
Ten would also have an option to become a 10 per cent shareholder in Foxtel's online streaming venture Presto within two years. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Finance News Update, what you need to know AAP 
WORLD FINANCE UPDATE: The Australian dollar is slightly higher after US stocks made solid gain on Friday. At 0630 …
